docs.lead_paragraph: In a preview of what is likely to be a recurring budget battle this year, the Senate today blocked an attempt by Democrats to restrict Congress's use of surplus Medicare revenues for a tax cut or general government spending. The effect of the vote was to leave on the table hundreds of billions of dollars over the next decade that President Bush and Congress may need to help pay for the administration's proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut and increased spending on the military and other programs.

headline.main: A Bill to Wall Off Medicare Revenue Fails

docs.abstract: Senate blocks Democratic attempt to restrict Congress's use of surplus Medicare revenues for tax cut or general government spending; Democrats, in preview of budget battle, warn vote shows Republicans will raid Medicare surplus to pay for Bush's proposals (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Bans European Meat, Fearing Spread of Virus The United States banned imports of animals and animal products from the European Union after learning that foot-and-mouth disease had spread to France from Britain. The Agriculture Department said it was taking the precaution to protect the domestic industry from a possible outbreak of the virus, which poses no danger to people but is devastating to cloven-hoofed animals. A1 Western Europe has chosen to deal with the virus largely by slaughtering and cremating infected animals rather than by inoculating them. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: From Mass at the convention center to lunch at the governor's mansion and prayers inside the bitterly divided Senate chamber, Cardinal Edward M. Egan used his first visit to the state capital today to seek support for the Catholic Church's position on issues ranging from insurance coverage for birth control services to state financing for parochial schools. The State Senate and Assembly are at an impasse over a provision in a package of women's health measures that would require insurance companies to cover birth control.

headline.main: Egan Takes Church's Issues To Albany

docs.abstract: Cardinal Edward M Egan uses his first visit to Albany to seek support from New York State Legislature for Roman Catholic Church's position on issues ranging from insurance for birth control services to state financing for parochial schools; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Fang Jing, wearing an apron depicting the female body over her own, greeted the women who had squeezed into the village's meeting room. And as babies played on the floor, Dr. Fang cheerfully discussed conception, pelvic infections and how to prevent sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS. It was a much needed lesson in this lush mountainous area of Yunnan Province, a region where disease is plentiful but health care hard to come by. Nearly 1 in 10 babies here dies by the age of 5, and more than half the seemingly healthy women suffer with chronic gynecological infections, studies have found.
docs.abstract: Dr Fang Jing's efforts to educate women in rural Bazuo, China, about their health described; photo; her project, sponsored by local goverment women's federation with Ford Foundation aid, offers financial incentives, including small-business loan program, to lure women into health system they avoid because of costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Zhang Youlian wept in the dirt courtyard surrounded by towering peaks, her tears spoke to her year of calamities. First, her 35-year-old husband fell ill and was taken from their rice fields to the hospital with chest pain that he had ignored for too long.

headline.main: As China Trims Health Care, the Rural Poor Suffer

docs.abstract: Huge numbers of China's 800 million rural people are in medical free fall as once-vaunted system of 'barefoot doctors' and free clinics disintegrates, side effect of market-oriented changes of past decade; central planners have withdrawn from people's lives, taking with them most subsidies for social services like health and education; rural health system has become hodgepodge of hospitals and clinics often privately run and almost always prohibitively expensive; UN reports health costs rose 400 to 500 percent from 1990 to 1997, so that rural Chinese have stopped seeing doctors except in extreme emergencies, enduring pain, infection and childbirth at home; suffering of Zhang Youlian and her family in Bazuo in Yunnan Province described; photos; map; UN report also documents rising tuberculosis and infant mortality rates; government officials acknowledge rural lag compared with cities and more prosperous coastal farming regions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 11 o'clock one night at the Hudson Valley Migrant Health Clinic and the pager affixed to Vince LaSalle's waist started beeping. Mr. LaSalle, a physician's assistant at the clinic here, had been closing up for the night. The call was from an anxious mother whose baby's raging fever would not break. So Mr. LaSalle and an outreach worker, Kenny Gould, jumped in their cars and headed out for a house call, winding through the unlighted back roads of the apple orchard country of Ulster County.

headline.main: Clinic Casts Lifeline to Isolated Migrant Workers

docs.abstract: Outreach workers from Hudson Valley (NY) Migrant Health Clinic tend to health needs of migrant farmworkers in Hudson Valley; migrants, mostly illegal immigrants who are wary of institutions, live a barebones existence; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Congress rescinded new ergonomics regulations last week, Democrats and union leaders said it was a victory for business at the expense of labor. Actually, it was more like a victory for workers' wallets at the possible expense of their bodies. Politicians like to pretend that their reforms are rescuing workers from predations of capitalists, but the capitalists generally do not get stuck with the bill. They prefer to pass the costs along, either through higher prices for their products or lower pay for their workers.

headline.main: The Big City; Workers Vote With Wallets On Job Safety

docs.abstract: John Tierney The Big City column, noting Congress is rescinding new ergonomics regulations last week, calls for debate on whether workers should be forced to pay for ergonomic safety (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five health plans that cover almost every resident of Minnesota will announce today that they are supporting standard treatment and prevention procedures for 50 common ailments like lower back pain, high blood pressure, diabetes and bladder infections. This is the first time all the major health plans in a state have collaborated to endorse a set of standard guidelines or protocols. Their support represents a major step toward the adoption of national ''best practice'' medical standards based on recognized scientific evidence.

headline.main: Minnesota Health Plans to Standardize Treatments

docs.abstract: Five health plans that cover almost every resident of Minnesota will support standard treatment and prevention procedures for 50 common ailments; their decision represents major step toward adoption of national 'best practice' medical standards based on recognized scientific evidence; health plans joining HealthPartners as sponsors of new standards are Minnesota Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Medica, PreferredOne and UCare Minnesota, which provides primary care coverage by University of Minnesota doctors for Medicare and Medicaid patients; new standards address concerns about patient safety and consistency of care that were recently articulated by Institute of Medicine of National Academy of Science (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An influential federal advisory commission says the financial condition of the nation's hospitals has significantly improved, so there is no need for Congress to increase their Medicare payments, despite insistent pleas from the industry. If Congress accepts the advice, as it often does, lawmakers will have more money available for new Medicare benefits like prescription drug coverage. In the last 18 months, elderly people seeking drug benefits have found themselves competing with hospitals, nursing homes and other providers for a limited pot of federal money.

headline.main: Cap Urged on Hospitals' Medicare Money

docs.abstract: Report by Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, influential federal advisory commission that advises Congress, says financial condition of nation's hospitals has significantly improved, so there is no need for Congress to increase Medicare payments, despite insistent pleas from industry; its findings discussed (M)
